displaytitle: Young migratory mother, originally from Texas, Edison, California
creditline: Gift of Alexander D. Stuart, Class of 1972, and Robin Stuart
signed: Signed and dated on recto: Dorothea Lange, 1940, for the Bureau of Agricultural Economics (U.S.D.A.)

titles.title: Young migratory mother, originally from Texas. On the day before the photograph was made, she and her husband traveled 35 miles each way to pick peas. They worked 5 hours each and together earned $2.25. They have two young children...Live in auto camp, Edison, Kern County, California, April 11, 1940
Young migratory mother, originally from Texas, Edison, California

makers.displaydate: 1895–1965; born Hoboken, NJ; died San Francisco, CA; active San Francisco, CA
makers.displaymaker: Dorothea Lange, 1895–1965; born Hoboken, NJ; died San Francisco, CA; active San Francisco, CA

texts.textentryhtml: Purchased by Alexander D. Stuart, December 23, 1989; gifted by Alexander D. Stuart, Class of 1972, and Robin Stuart to Princeton University Art Museum, October 2023.

After beginning her career in portrait photography, Lange became one of the most acclaimed American documentary photographers of the twentieth century. Working under the auspices of the Farm Securities Administration—the New Deal program established to ameliorate the devastating economic and social consequences of the Great Depression—Lange photographed conditions in the Dust Bowl, the southwestern region devastated by erosion and drought, which caused mass displacement as individuals and families moved west to become migrant workers. On assignment in central California, Lange was returning home when she noticed a pea-pickers camp. As Lange remembers, she initially ignored her impulse to stop at the camp and drove for miles before, “following instinct, not reason,” she turned around, a decision that resulted in this and other photographs documenting the migrants’ plight.

displaymaker: Dorothea Lange, 1895–1965; born Hoboken, NJ; died San Francisco, CA; active San Francisco, CA
